partial_orders.reason: Both edits remove references to the same instance variable `self._is_stopped` from the Thread class. Edit 0 removes the initialization of `_is_stopped` in the constructor, while Edit 1 removes the assignment to `_is_stopped` in the `_stop` method. These edits reference the exact same symbol (`self._is_stopped`) and are part of a coordinated removal of this attribute from the class. Either edit can be made first without causing parse errors, and both are mechanically linked as part of the same refactoring task to eliminate the `_is_stopped` attribute.

Edit 0 removes the `_is_stopped` attribute from the Thread class constructor, while Edit 1 changes the `is_alive` method to use `self._stopped.is_set()` instead of `self._is_stopped`. These edits reference the exact same symbol (`_is_stopped`) - Edit 0 removes its definition and Edit 1 removes its usage, replacing it with the equivalent `_stopped.is_set()` call. This is a coordinated refactoring where both edits must happen together to maintain code consistency. The removal of the attribute definition and its usage reference the same symbol and form a direct code dependency. Either edit can be applied first since both are syntactically valid independently, but together they complete the refactoring of removing the redundant `_is_stopped` attribute.
